importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article reports the occurrence of a major AWS outage, highlighting the real-time impact of internet infrastructure failures on global digital services.
The last major AWS outage occurred in 2021, indicating that such events, while rare, are not uncommon in the context of cloud computing infrastructure.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The outage began in the morning and was resolved by 6:35 AM ET, showing the duration and timeline of the disruption, which affected millions of users globally.

keyTakeAways: The internet's reliance on a few dominant cloud providers, such as Amazon Web Services (AWS), makes it vulnerable to widespread outages.
A failure in the Domain Name System (DNS) prevented users from accessing AWS-hosted services, even though the data remained safe.
The root cause of the outage is currently unknown, but it likely stemmed from a technical fault in AWS’s DNS infrastructure or a failure in a key service like DynamoDB.
The frequency of such outages highlights the lack of redundancy and competitive alternatives in the cloud computing ecosystem.

Past large-scale outages, such as the 2024 CrowdStrike software bug and AT&T’s 11-hour network failure, demonstrate how cascading failures in critical systems can have global economic and operational consequences.

namedEntities.name: Amazon Web Services (AWS)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A major cloud computing platform that hosts critical online services such as banking, social media, e-commerce, and airline booking systems.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: AWS is central to the functioning of many internet services, and its outage disrupted thousands of websites and apps globally, illustrating the fragility of internet infrastructure.

namedEntities.name: Domain Name System (DNS)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A system that translates human-readable web addresses (like amazon.com) into IP addresses that computers can understand.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The DNS outage prevented users from accessing AWS-hosted services, leading to a widespread disruption despite data being safely stored.

namedEntities.name: DynamoDB
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A database service offered by AWS that stores customer and other application data for companies.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Customers were unable to access data in DynamoDB due to the DNS failure, highlighting how critical data services depend on stable cloud infrastructure.

namedEntities.name: EC2
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A virtual server service used by companies to build and run online applications.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The outage affected EC2 services, which are widely used by businesses for hosting web applications and services.

namedEntities.name: CrowdStrike
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A cybersecurity software company whose software update caused a global IT outage in 2024.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The 2024 CrowdStrike incident provides historical context for the risks of cascading failures in global IT systems, emphasizing the danger of centralized software systems.

namedEntities.name: AT&T
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A major telecommunications provider whose network experienced multiple outages, including an 11-hour meltdown.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: AT&T’s past outages illustrate how infrastructure failures in key network providers can disrupt essential services like remote work and gig economy jobs.

namedEntities.name: NymVPN
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A cybersecurity firm whose chief digital officer, Rob Jardin, commented on the fragility of the internet due to centralized cloud reliance.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: NymVPN’s expert commentary highlights concerns about the lack of redundancy in internet infrastructure and the concentration of digital services in a few cloud providers.

namedEntities.name: Mike Chapple
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A cybersecurity expert and IT professor at the University of Notre Dame.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Chapple provides expert analysis on how minor technical faults in cloud services can have massive real-world impacts due to interdependency.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A major outage on Amazon Web Services (AWS) disrupted thousands of websites and online services globally on Monday, October 20, 2025, lasting several hours. The root cause appears to be a failure in the Domain Name System (DNS), which prevented users from accessing AWS-hosted data and applications, even though the data itself remained safe. This outage underscores the fragility of the modern internet, which depends heavily on a few dominant cloud platforms like AWS. Experts note that such failures highlight a critical lack of redundancy and competitive alternatives, as the internet was originally designed to be decentralized and resilient. The incident echoes previous large-scale outages, such as the 2024 CrowdStrike software bug and AT&T’s network failures, demonstrating how technical faults in key systems can lead to widespread global disruption and economic loss.
title: The internet just had another global outage. Why does this keep happening?
